metadata.titleEn: A long term hourly eddy covariance dataset of consistently processed CO2 and H2O Fluxes from the Tibetan Alpine Steppe at Nam Co (2005 - 2019)
metadata.description: The data set contains nearly 15 years of eddy covariance data  from an alpine steppe ecosystem on the central Tibetan Plateau.The data was processed following standardized quality control methods to allow for comparability between the different years of  our record and with other data sets. To ensure meaningful  estimates of ecosystem atmosphere exchange, careful application of the following correction procedures and analyses was necessary: (1) Due to the remote location, continuous maintenance of the eddy covariance (EC) system was not always possible, so that cleaning and calibration of the sensors was performed irregularly. Furthermore, the high proportion of bare soil and high wind speeds led to accumulation of dirt in the measurement path of the infrared gas analyzer (IRGA). The installation of the sensor in such a challenging environment resulted in a considerable drift in CO2 and H2O gas density measurements. If not accounted for, this concentration bias may distort the estimation of the carbon uptake. We applied a modified drift correction procedure following Fratini et al. (2014) which, instead of a linear interpolation  between calibration dates, uses the CO2 concentration measurements  from the Mt. Waliguan atmospheric observatory as reference time series. (2) We applied rigorous quality filtering of the calculated fluxes to retain only fluxes which represent actual physical processes. (3) During the long measurement period, there were several buildings constructed in the near vicinity of the EC system. We investigated the influence of these obstacles on the turbulent flow regime to identify fluxes with uncertain land cover contribution and exclude them from subsequent computations. (4) We calculated the de-facto standard correction for instrument surface heating during cold conditions (hereafter called sensor self heating correction) following Burba et al. (2008) and a revision of the original method following Frank and Massman (2020). (5)Subsequently, we applied the traditional and widely used gap filling procedure following Reichstein et al. (2005) to provide a more complete overview of the annual net ecosystem CO2 exchange.(6) We estimated the flux uncertainty by calculating the random flux error (RE) following Finkelstein and Sims (2001) and by using the standard deviation of the fluxes used for gap filling(NEE_fsd) as a measure for spatial and temporal variation.
metadata.instructions:
File name: NAMORS_EC_2005-2019.csv. The file contains the EddyPro full_output (https://www.licor.com/env/support/EddyPro/topics/output-files-full-output.html) and biomet data, quality flags for quality filtering and fetch filtering, the CO2 fluxes corrected for sensor self heating effects, random uncertainty measures as propagated via WPL correction and the REddyProc gap filling results (https://www.bgc-jena.mpg.de/bgi/index.php/Services/REddyProcWebOutput).
File name: NAMORS_EC_2005-2019_varnames_units.csv. The file contains the variable descriptions and physical units for the above mentioned dataset.
Version 2 with enhanced calculations and data  processing after peer-review(https://essd.copernicus.org/preprints/essd-2020-63/#discussion). The file "NAMORS_EC_2005-2019_v2.txt" contains the EddyProfull_output (https://www.licor.com/env/support/EddyPro/topics/output-files-full-output.html)and biomet data, quality flags for quality filtering, the CO2fluxes corrected for sensor self heating effects and the REddyProcgap filling results(https://www.bgc-jena.mpg.de/bgi/index.php/Services/REddyProcWebOutput).The file "NAMORS_EC_2005-2019_varnames_units_v2.txt" contains thevariable descriptions and physical units for the above mentioneddataset. The uploaded files are tab-delimited .txt files with"-9999" representing missing data.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific challenges and correction procedures involved in collecting and processing eddy covariance data from remote and challenging environments like the Tibetan Alpine Steppe?
Feature Specification.Answer: irregular cleaning and calibration of sensors, accumulation of dirt affecting sensor readings, drift in CO2 and H2O measurements, using CO2 concentration measurements from a reference observatory for drift correction, quality filtering of fluxes, evaluating the influence of nearby constructions on turbulent flow, applying sensor self-heating corrections, gap filling, uncertainty estimation methods

Quantification.Question: How many years of data are included in the eddy covariance dataset from the Tibetan Alpine Steppe?

Comparison.Question: How do the data correction procedures applied in a dataset from the Tibetan Alpine Steppe compare to those used in other remote eddy covariance sites in terms of addressing sensor drift and environmental challenges?
Comparison.Answer: In a dataset from the Tibetan Alpine Steppe, a modified drift correction procedure is used, which references CO2 concentration measurements from a nearby atmospheric observatory instead of linear interpolation between calibration dates. This approach may differ from other remote eddy covariance sites that might rely on different reference data or interpolation methods. Additionally, the dataset addresses challenges such as dirt accumulation and high wind speeds, which might be more pronounced compared to other sites, requiring tailored correction procedures.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors cause the need for rigorous quality filtering of flux data in eddy covariance datasets collected from remote and challenging environments like the Tibetan Alpine Steppe?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Due to the remote location of the eddy covariance system, continuous maintenance was not always possible, leading to irregular cleaning and calibration of sensors. Additionally, the high proportion of bare soil and high wind speeds resulted in the accumulation of dirt in the measurement path of the infrared gas analyzer (IRGA), causing a drift in CO2 and H2O gas density measurements. These factors necessitate rigorous quality filtering to retain fluxes that represent actual physical processes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of irregular sensor maintenance and cleaning on the accuracy and reliability of a dataset collected in remote and challenging environments like the Tibetan Alpine Steppe?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Irregular sensor maintenance and cleaning can lead to the accumulation of dirt in the measurement path of instruments such as the infrared gas analyzer (IRGA), causing considerable drift in CO2 and H2O gas density measurements. This drift, if uncorrected, can distort the estimation of carbon uptake, impacting the accuracy and reliability of the dataset. A modified drift correction procedure may be necessary to address these issues and ensure meaningful estimates of ecosystem-atmosphere exchange.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary aim of creating a dataset of long-term half-hourly eddy covariance CO2 and H2O fluxes from the Tibetan Alpine Steppe?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary aim of creating a dataset of long-term half-hourly eddy covariance CO2 and H2O fluxes from the Tibetan Alpine Steppe is to provide a comprehensive record of ecosystem-atmosphere exchanges over nearly 15 years. This involves consistent data processing and quality control to ensure comparability across different years and with other datasets. The dataset serves to enhance understanding of carbon and water flux dynamics in alpine steppe ecosystems, particularly in challenging environments like the central Tibetan Plateau, where factors such as soil conditions, wind, and sensor drift can affect data accuracy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures must be followed to ensure the correction of sensor drift in long-term CO2 and H2O flux measurements in remote alpine steppes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To correct sensor drift in long-term CO2 and H2O flux measurements in remote alpine steppes, a modified drift correction procedure is necessary. This involves using CO2 concentration measurements from a reference time series, such as the Mt. Waliguan atmospheric observatory, instead of linear interpolation between calibration dates. This approach helps in accounting for potential biases in concentration measurements due to irregular sensor calibration and environmental challenges.
